p.s: The foster child Helen in the novel Gun Love is a talkative, lovely child with a tough childhood and she often mixes her true memories with her false memories up.
It is remarkable that she is traumatised and much influenced by her childhood and that she is a fool of the American Dream, because she never get in better conditions.
In the following part, I will analyse her in detail.
Helen is aan eight-year-old foster child who lookeslooks like a five-year-old child and is built very small (cf. ll. 1-2).
She has a childish and lovable appearance which is shown by Pearl, thinking she was younger (cf. l. 2), her behavior (cf. l. 41) and the things she likes (cf. ll. 18-20).
By talking nonstop (l. 5) she findfinds a way in dealing with her tough childhood.
On the one hand she may disregard her trauma but on the other hand it could could help her talking to others about it for dealing with her problems indirectly.
She also has no idea (l. 5) about what she is talking because she is very young and can notcannot understand her life and her experiences fully.
It also shows that she missed out being a child and doing childish things because she had to handle hard topics, for example poverty, so that is a reason for her younger and childish appearance.
OneOn the other hand she never learned much about growing up, because there were too many different homes and people in her life (cf. ll. 11-12), which is also an aspect for her childishness.
Her surrounding was not like a home and not very loving because she had for example to sleep on the floor (l. 16).
That is why she is so lovely, soft and childish now, because she likes lovely things like forehead kisses (l. 19) and cats (l. 34) which are cute (l. 34) and soft like her personality.
Her behaviour towards Pearl (cf. ll. 41-42) shows her needing of love and a mother figure that she never had.
She has no sense (l. 23) in her life so she adds things that did not happen.
She speaks about herself in the third person (cf. l. 17) because it is a senseless life for her which not feels like she is the person that is living it so she hides it before herself.
Nobody corrects her (cf. l. 17) because they have sympathy for her.
The other foster childrenchild Leo (l. 22) is like a family member because he always hangs out with her.

She loves her family and her friends Lulu, Gina and Romey (cf. ll. 32-33) because she would call them if she newknew how to use the 17 phones she got for every foster home she were before (cf. l. 30) so she a place to call home.
Because of her hard childhood and missing of love, she is very lovable and needing nowadays and she talks very much to deal with her past.
